g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
being cognizant of the specific role of key actors and institutions
. A specific assessment of innovation may focus on part of such a list of
indicators, depending on what aspect of innovation i
s being studied, whether the analysis takes a more
or less systemic perspective, and the specific technology and geography considered. Similarly,
innovation policies may be designed to specifically boost only some of these aspects, depending
n country/region is committed to strengthen a given technology or phase.
The systemic approach to innovation and transition dynamics (see also Cross
chapter) has advanced our understanding of the complexity of the innovation proc
importance of assessing the efficiency and effectiveness in producing, diffusing and exploiting
, including how the existing stock of knowledge may be recombined and
. There remains a crucial need for more relevant and
In the context of climate mitigation, innovation is a means to an end; therefore, there is the need to
consider the processes by which the output of innovation (e.g., patents) are translated into real
. Currently, a set of quantitative metrics that, collectively, can help get a picture of innovation in
a particular energy technology or set of energy technologies is not available. Also the understanding of
how to systematically use qualitative indicator
s to characterise the more intangible aspects of the energy
innovation system and to improve front
end innovation decisions is still lacking
